transcript:
Welcome to Behind the Ticker.
I'm Brad Roth, Chief Investment Officer of Thor Financial Technologies, and portfolio manager
of THLV, the Thor Low Volatility ETF.
Behind the Ticker, uncovers the inner workings of the ETF industry.
We will interview portfolio managers and ETF service providers to dive deep into their
work lives and their businesses.
We will learn the inner workings of their strategies and what drives them as they continue
to grow their company.
Many of these individuals are entrepreneurs, and will have unique and compelling insights
to share as much goes on behind the Ticker.
Please note, nothing in this show is investment advice, and it is meant solely for
educational and entertainment purposes only.
Welcome to Behind the Ticker episode 3.
Today we have Daniel Snover.
He is the founder of PMV Capital as well as the portfolio manager of the ARP ETF, which stands
for adaptive risk parity.
If you don't know what risk parity is, today you're going to get a lesson on it.
If you don't have it in your portfolio, you're going to get reasons why you absolutely
should.
I think Daniel and his team do a wonderful job with their systematic approach.
They take towards risk parity.
So I hope you enjoy this episode with Daniel Snover.
Hey Daniel, welcome to Behind the Ticker.
Thanks for joining the show.
Nice to see you, Brett. Thanks for having me on.
So before we get started, we're going to talk about your adaptive risk parity ETF today.
We're going to talk about your firm.
But why don't you tell a little bit, tell the people a little bit about who you are,
your background, and how you got to where you are today.
Yeah sure. So I started in portfolio management and that's allocation right during the
financial crisis in the 09 period. So I think a lot of people's early experiences determined
their outlook on investing and how they think about things and that's certainly true for me.
So I've always been concerned with figuring out how we manage this market risk systematic risk
and my approach to that has been through asset allocation and mixing in stocks, bonds,
commodities in a way that really manages that risk.
And so that's what we're doing at PMV and that's kind of the origin of my story.
So at PMV, we'll talk about the ETF.
But what else do you get? Do you guys do anything else for clients?
Do you do sub advisory work or anything else at the firm?
We do. We have some separate accounts that we manage.
But our primary focus is really on the ETF and but we do we have a series of risk-based
allocation models that are in this risk-perity style and we'll use our ETF as active component
and then we'll mix in other static positions to kind of get people to where they need to be.
But we do we have a series of those SMA portfolios.
Yeah that's great. So I guess I'm curious to what made you
really start the firm. I mean you you started your career like you said in 2008.
But what made you take that entrepreneurial leap and say I'm going to go out and do this myself?
Yeah so the firm I was working with at that school, I became an owner in and actually sold
that business in 2019 and I worked with the firm that bought us for about nine months and
wasn't really doing the portfolio management side that I wanted and so I thought you know I need
to go off and do my own thing. So the two partners I found at P&V with that worked on
in a previous capacity for about 10 years that were good friends of mine and so I brought
them the idea of starting our own thing and so in 2020 the firm actually found it and then
we kind of quickly realized that the industry was moving you know towards we needed an ETF to really
get our strategy out. You know advisors don't really want to pay 3040 basis points for an SMA
and even our current SMAs we offer without additional charge to the advisors because we've
mixed in our ETF product. So I think really to compete and given the act of nature of the strategy
with the tax consequences you know we needed the ETF structure so we spent all last year
getting that set up and our goal was to have launched before year end and the ETF was launched
in December. Yeah so we launched it about the same time so yeah great fairly new to the
whole space but so you manage like you said the ARP ETF which is the adaptive
risk parity ETF but you know what does risk parity really what is it designed to achieve?
What is the goal of risk parity from a high kind of theoretical level? Yeah the highest level of
goal is to remove as much as possible what's called this systematic risk or the market risk
from the portfolio. So the idea is to just capture the return with the risk premium of the underlying
assets and to combine those assets in a way to where the systematic risk of each one of them
offsets and so it's really about maximizing the diversification benefits of the you know stocks
bonds commodities. So in everything you do at the firm is 100% systematic correct so you guys aren't
behind the scenes really trying to pull strings or making market calls. Right so yeah it's systematic
because you know really it's just a process and even if you're another manager let's say you're
managing a you know a value strategy you know if you have a process whereby you screen stocks for a
certain metric and you have a rebalancing time frame and you know you can eventually just get it
to a process and so we think that's important because if you have an idea about how something might
work and you want to try it out well then you might want to put that into a system and run it
through different scenarios to see you know how that might play out. So yeah we we are big
proponents of a systematic process whether that's actually you know including technical data
and market data or however it's structured but yeah we think a defined process has very beneficial.
So are you continually working on and enhancing your systems or is it something that you know you
built to be robust and doesn't really need to change over time? Yeah it's built to be robust and so
we don't imagine it changing at all I'm going forward you know we of course have a discussion to
update it but the system that we have put in place now is something I've been developing for a
little bit more than 10 years now and so in the beginning it started off with an Excel spreadsheet
and kind of three set portfolios that we would rotate in between and that advanced you know
so on and so forth until the point where we are now where any changes we make are really on the
margin they're not really you know the underlying asset classes that we trade or the way we think
about markets or the way we determine the position sizes you know all those things have really been
sorted out through through the time and so many changes we would make I think are going to be
pretty marginal. So if you so you started building this 10 years ago along the way I mean you
started an Excel did you have to learn how to code I mean are you are you self taught in that
area as well to build this thing out? I wish I could tell you I knew how to code but I don't
yeah it's not my previous firm there was someone who worked there that had coding experience
and we also used a portfolio management software where people at that software company
knew how to code and build strategies and so we hired them to develop some of the initial ones
and then PMV or Chief Operating Officer Mark the John Antonio knows how to code and so he's built
the current iteration and but yet now I kind of just direct direct the process.
I was the same I mean I've been doing this for probably 10 years as well in the systematic space
exactly 10 years would be 2013 and I start looking into back into the code and I'm so afraid
to touch anything because if I if I I could break the whole thing yeah really quickly and so I
I have to rely on others for that but you learn a lot I never thought I would I'd be in the space
where I was having to to at least familiarize myself with it. Yeah that's a definitely.
So tell me tell me about the strategy behind ARP right we know it's risk parity but like
what's really dive deep into what you're trying to accomplish how you know the composition
and the portfolio tends to look and change so you know let's really dive into to what this
what investors are going to see when they invest in ARP. Yeah great so I think what's exciting
about the strategy is that it's really integrated the macroeconomic environment and not look
with the systematic process and so what I mean by that is when I said risk parity is trying
to minimize the effects of the market cycle on the portfolio. I think we need to start there
and kind of talk about and define what I mean by systematic risk and what goes into that because
once you get to the asset class level there's not individual stock risk right so the risk that
is and here it in and the overall stock market for example is the risks that are driven by the
underlying economy and the cycles that we're experiencing and we're going through a very interesting
one right now which we can talk about if you like but what we're going through right now in the
economy is the same tradeoff that we always get which is this tradeoff between economic growth
on the one hand and inflation on the other. So if you don't think about investing at all you just
think about the economy and the market cycles the what's what's driving those cycles through time is
economic growth and inflation and that mechanism is is really a debt cycle because when when inflation
is low and and economic growth is low you know the fed the central bank whatever country you're in
will step in to spur growth and they can do that up until a point when inflation becomes a concern
right and then obviously reverse course so that that tradeoff is the tradeoff of the market cycle
which then translates into the systematic risk that we see inherent in each asset class so what's
interesting too is that there's not a different market risk or systematic risk for stocks or
bonds or commodities because it's people often think well there's the risk of stocks and then there's
the risk of bonds and then there's the risk of commodities right but in reality it's one systematic
risk it's it's they're all driven by the same underlying economy they're just influenced differently
by those tradeoffs so if we start with stocks for example when do stocks go down when when do stocks
hit a bad environment and that's when economic growth is slowing or when inflation is high right but
if you think about commodities when do commodities you know we're talking broad commodities here
tend to perform best and that's when economic growth is high and inflation is high
right so what risk parity is trying to do is to identify which broad asset gives the most direct
exposure to the changes in those underlying variables that you can such that you can mix them together
in a way that offsets that systematic risk and so if you think in your mind about a four quadrant
where and you need five hundred this but I was just going to bring it up because I was on your site and
you've made a very complicated idea very easy to understand when you go on your website you have a
quad it and then you you show over time when we are in these different environments and what would
be the best investment during that particular year at month? Yep exactly and that research is
really from Ray Dalio and Bridgewater to familiar with them and risk parity is really an offshoot
of the all weather strategies so if you hear all weather and risk parity they're referencing the
same thing and so you know the macro research is really driven by them and so on a on a static
basis the the classic or static risk parity portfolio will try to balance the risk between the
four environments that are created by increases and decreases in growth and inflation right because
this this portfolio construction idea so if you think about building a portfolio and you want to
maximize the certification which is the same the same you want to minimize risk right then
the way you do that is is by having positions that have different correlations when one goes up
the other goes down right and you need to have the same risk allocated each one because
take the sixty forty portfolio you know if the stocks enough portfolio or five times or four times
the risk here then the bonds then when you do the allocation on the risk stocks are counting
for more than 90% of the risk of that sixty forty portfolio right so if you look at the correlation
the correlation of a sixty forty portfolio to let's say the S&P 500 is around 0.95 which is telling
you you're not getting any diversification benefits so the risk parity concept is about balancing
risk between the correlated positions. Well I think the average investor learned that last year right
you had both fixed income and equities you got the full brunt of the downside and the lack of
the diversification benefits of that portfolio last year right. Yep that's exactly right. So what
primary factors help drive better risk adjusted return in your model right so
it's let me ask that a different way I should say and what environments you should always
own risk parity in my opinion right I think it always deserves a spotting report for you but when
are you going to produce the most alpha in this portfolio is that in recessionary environments
or and market wall and when I speak when I say market wall equity wall. Yeah so times
that question I think it would be helpful to explain what we're doing as compared to a static
or traditional risk parity because we have an adaptive process whereby we identify the momentum
trends that are created by these economic environments so the name of our company PMV is the equation
for momentum and so what we're doing our thesis essentially is that the broad momentum trends that you see
if you just pull up a graph of let's say commodities right the the broad trends that you see
in these underlying asset classes are created by the underlying economic environment and so instead
of passively allocating risk between the four scenarios we identify where we are in the
macro cycle from the relationships of the assets and then we use that to determine our underlying
allocation so you know if you take the past couple of years as a great example
obviously broad commodities were up a lot from 2020 through June of last year and at the same time
treasuries long duration treasuries were down close to a similar amount and so if you look at the
spread the difference of those that's telling you you're in a high growth high inflation environment
and that's been coming down those trends have been coming down to where right now we we see the
market pricing and slowing growth and slowing inflation which you know whether that persists
or whether the market's correct you know that's kind of what we're seeing is getting priced in
and so you know when our strategy will perform best is when we are in an environment when those trends
are persisting right and when more than one asset class is performing well so if we're in an
environment when the only you know asset class that's going up is what's like commodities then
it's going to be hard for us to diversify because without giving up return because any
risk that we allocate to outside of that is going to be a drag on the performance right
and risk parity portfolios you know will tend to have a hard time in a rising rate in
environment because if you think about any asset whether it's stocks bonds commodities you can
determine the value of those assets by the present value of their future cash flows right
so as you raise the interest rates or discount rates that in theory brings down the value of all
assets and so and that environment it's hard to find possibly trending things in a diversify
when you know the correlations a lot of those assets are are coming together and and their
and their returns are going down together so when you're starting to build these portfolios out
and from a holdings and holding construction perspective can you guys go anywhere or you just
buying broad broad equities broad commodities broad fixed income I mean can you kind of go anywhere
or is it just kind of broad ETFs yeah so our investment universe is set we have a different asset
classes that we trade and I'll mention what those are but I also want to mention that it's a fun
to fund structure so our ETF trades other ETFs and the reason we set it up that way is that we could
trade a futures contract on each one of the underlying indexes or assets that we trade but then
our investors would be subject to the 6040 tax treatment of the futures contract so by taking out
a little bit extra expense from the underlying internal expenses of the Vanguard I shares
other ETFs that we trade you know we can through the custom you know basket creation process
minimize to the extent possible the capcapes so that's why we you know even that's a little bit
more expensive shows that fund of unstructured and then you know I mentioned the four different
market environments so when equities are performing well we can go US international or
so no sectors no individual stocks just broad assets US international and you
thought and then our merging site and on the bond side we have short duration
debils and long term 20 plus year treasuries because no other bond is a diversifier to stock
right if you go down the credit scale you're just getting correlation stocks right so we just want
treasuries on the fixed income side for commodities we just trade the broad commodities basket
but then we also separate physical gold out separately because in a stack-plationary environment
which you know I anticipate us being and then you know you don't want broad commodities you know
broad commodities peak last June right as economic growth started slowing and you saw a
gold you know rallying much more over this recent period so those are the assets so we're
using inside of the basket let's just stick with equities right so you have three different places to
choose from inside that equity universe you're then applying momentum calculations to figure out
the waiting of those asset classes on top of the you know the quad decision if we can call it that
yeah great question so we have a monthly rebalance and we start with the clean slate right so
no set targets to any of the assets that I mentioned then what we do is we measure the momentum of
our various look back periods because the momentum that I'm talking about is persistent we think
somewhere between three months and 12 months but if you just picked one window then you're you know
going to get a different response or right so we take multiple readings between a three to 12 month
period and then we essentially just develop risk-perity portfolios over each of those periods and
blend them together so the first thing that you want to do is invest in assets going up so the
first thing we screen for over each of our windows are positively trending asset classes then what you
want to do is of those assets that are going up of those positively trending assets to the extent
possible you want to minimize the risk and that's where you look at correlations and you know
standard deviations all that and so within each of those periods of assets going up you try to
balance the risk the best you can so are there guardrails on waiting inside of a quad so
you know could theoretically you invest just 100% US and not in international emerging markets
or are there certain guardrails where you can go yeah great question so there's a 40% max
to each of those assets that I mentioned so if US international and emerging we're all

you couldn't theory go on a percent equity but it would not be all US it would be some
